Towards Achieving Near-optimal Utility for Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning via Data Generation and Parameter Distortion

Xiaojin Zhang xiaojinzhang@ust.hk Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyClear Water BayChina ,  Kai Chen kaichen@cse.ust.hk Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyClear Water BayChina  and  Qiang Yang qyang@cse.ust.hk WeBank and Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyChina
(2022)
Abstract.

Federated learning (FL) enables participating parties to collaboratively build a global model with boosted utility without disclosing private data information. Appropriate protection mechanisms have to be adopted to fulfill the requirements in preserving privacy and maintaining high model utility. The nature of the widely-adopted protection mechanisms including Randomization Mechanism and Compression Mechanism is to protect privacy via distorting model parameter. We measure the utility via the gap between the original model parameter and the distorted model parameter. We want to identify under what general conditions privacy-preserving federated learning can achieve near-optimal utility via data generation and parameter distortion. To provide an avenue for achieving near-optimal utility, we present an upper bound for utility loss, which is measured using two main terms called variance-reduction and model parameter discrepancy separately. Our analysis inspires the design of appropriate protection parameters for the protection mechanisms to achieve near-optimal utility and meet the privacy requirements simultaneously. The main techniques for the protection mechanism include parameter distortion and data generation, which are generic and can be applied extensively. Furthermore, we provide an upper bound for the trade-off between privacy and utility, which together with the lower bound illustrated in NFL form the conditions for achieving optimal trade-off.

federated learning, privacy, utility, efficiency, trade-off,divergence, optimization

1. Introduction

The popularity of distributed learning has grown as a result of the expansion of massive data sets. Data possessed by one company is not permitted to be shared to others due to the enforcement of data privacy laws like the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Federated learning (FL) (McMahan et al., 2016, 2017; Konečnỳ et al., 2016a, b) meets this requirement by allowing multiple parties to train a machine learning model collaboratively without sharing private data. In recent years, FL has achieved significant progress in developing privacy-preserving machine learning systems.

We consider a horizontal federated learning (HFL) setting. A total of K𝐾K clients upload respective local models to the server, who is responsible for aggregating multiple local models into a global model. There are a variety of application scenarios that use this scheme for federated learning ((McMahan et al., 2016, 2017; Yang et al., 2019a, b)). Although the private data of each client is not shared with other collaborators, it was revealed that exposed gradients of learnt models could be used by semi-honest adversaries to recover private training images with pixel-level accuracy (e.g., DLG (Zhu and Han, 2020), Inverting Gradients (Geiping et al., 2020), Improved DLG (Zhao et al., 2020), GradInversion (Yin et al., 2021)), referred to as the gradient leakage attacking. Lots of attacking mechanisms reconstructed the private data via minimizing a candidate image in relation to a loss function that gauges the separation between the shared and candidate gradients. From an information theory point of view, the amount of information about private data that a semi-honest party can infer from exchanged information is inherently determined by the statistical dependency between private data and publicly exchanged information. The semi-honest adversaries ((Zhu et al., 2019; Zhu and Han, 2020; He et al., 2019)) can exploit this dependency to recover the private training images with pixel-level accuracy from exchanged gradients of learned models. Preserving privacy is of immense practical importance when federating across different parties. Keeping potential privacy leakage at a manageable level is a crucial necessity for sustaining privacy.

The fundamental requirement on privacy-preserving federated learning (PPFL) is to maintain potential privacy leakage below an acceptable level. To protect private data of the participants, many protection mechanisms have been proposed, such as Randomization Mechanism (Geyer et al., 2017; Truex et al., 2020; Abadi et al., 2016), Secret Sharing (Shamir, 1979; Blakley, 1979; Bonawitz et al., 2017), Homomorphic Encryption (HE) (Gentry, 2009; Zhang et al., 2020), and Compression Mechanism (Nori et al., 2021). The essence of these protection mechanisms is to distort the exchanged model parameter. For example, Randomization Mechanism adds noise that follows some predefined distributions on the model parameter, and Compression Mechanism distorts the original model parameter to the extent that some dimensions are eliminated.

The distorted model parameter might make the aggregated model less accurate and result in a positive amount of utility loss, as compared to model training without distorting model parameter. Zhang et al. (2022a) proposed the No Free Lunch theorem (NFL) that builds a unified framework to depict the relationship between privacy and utility in federated learning. The privacy and utility are measured via distortion extent, a metric that quantifies the difference of data distributions before and after privacy protection. NFL provides a lower bound for the weighted summation of privacy leakage and utility loss. A natural question comes out: is it possible to achieve near-optimal utility subject to the requirement on privacy leakage? In this work, we provide an affirmative answer for a special form of measurement for utility. We further derive an upper bound for the trade-off between privacy and utility (see Theorem 6.12). These two theoretical bounds together lead to the optimal trade-off between privacy and utility.

1.1. Our Contribution

We are interested in analyzing the consistency between generalization and privacy-preserving. The utility loss of client k𝑘k (denoted as ϵu,ksubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑘\epsilon_{u,k}) measures the variation in utility of client k𝑘k with the federated model drawn from unprotected distribution and the utility of the federated model drawn from protected distribution. To provide an avenue for achieving near-optimal utility, we first provide an upper bound for utility loss, which is measured using two main terms called variance-reduction and model parameter discrepancy separately. With the constraint on privacy leakage, the model parameter discrepancy is then determined. The upper bound on utility loss can be set to zero via adjusting the sampling probability appropriately, resulting in near-optimal utility.

  • •

    To derive the bound for utility loss, we use bias-variance decomposition, which could be interpreted as generalization-risk decomposition. The upper bound for utility loss (Theorem 6.1) measures the trade-off between variance-reduction and model parameter discrepancy.

  • •

    With the requirement on privacy leakage, we can determine the least amount of distortion extent (Lemma 6.6). Given the total variation distance, we can derive the variance of the added noise according to Lemma 6.7. To utility is further influenced by the sampling probability p𝑝p that is used for constructing the mini-batch (Theorem 6.11).

  • •

    Inspired by the theoretical analyses, we design an algorithm that achieves near-optimal utility and simultaneously satisfies the requirements on privacy leakage. The whole algorithm is illustrated in Algorithm 1.

  • •

    We provide an upper bound for the weighted summation of privacy leakage and utility loss (see Theorem 6.12). This bound together with the bound shown in NFL ((Zhang et al., 2022a)) form the optimal trade-off between privacy and utility. This theorem informs us how to achieve optimal privacy-utility trade-offs in Theorem 6.14, and implies the conditions when the proposed mechanisms achieve the optimal utility loss given the privacy leakage, and also provides an avenue for achieving the optimal privacy leakage given the utility loss.

2. Related Work

Attacking Mechanisms in Federated Learning

We focus on semi-honest adversaries who faithfully follow the federated learning protocol but may infer private information of other participants based on exposed model information. In HFL, Zhu et al. (2019); Zhu and Han (2020); Geiping et al. (2020); Zhao et al. (2020); Yin et al. (2021) demonstrate that adversaries could exploit gradient information to restore the private image data to pixel-level accuracy,with distinct settings of prior distributions and conditional distributions.

Protection Mechanisms in Federated Learning

A variety of protection mechanisms have been proposed in HFL to prevent private data from being deduced by adversarial participants,and the most popular ones are Homomorphic Encryption (HE) (Gentry, 2009; Zhang et al., 2020), Randomization Mechanism (Geyer et al., 2017; Truex et al., 2020; Abadi et al., 2016), Secret Sharing (Shamir, 1979; Blakley, 1979; Bonawitz et al., 2017) and Compression Mechanism (Nori et al., 2021). Another school of FL (Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Gu et al., 2021) tries to protect privacy by splitting a neural network into private and public models,and sharing only the public one (Kang et al., 2021; Gu et al., 2021).

Model Accuracy

Sajadmanesh and Gatica-Perez (2021) introduce how to find a suitable parameter to minimize the variance, the relationship between variance reduction and utility loss is not considered. Kaya and Dumitras (2021) show that label smoothing can increase accuracy and protection at the same time. de Luca et al. (2022) introduce the use of data augmentation, which includes higher accuracy on unseen clients, mitigate data heterogeneity, and much sparser communication.

Privacy-Utility Trade-off

In the past decade,there has been wide interest in understanding utility-privacy trade-off. Sankar et al. (2013) quantified utility via accuracy,and privacy via entropy. They provided a utility-privacy tradeoff region for i.i.d. data sources with known distribution based on rate-distortion theory. They left the problem of quantifying utility-privacy tradeoffs for more general sources as a challenging open problem.

Makhdoumi and Fawaz (2013) modeled the utility-privacy tradeoff according to the framework proposed by du Pin Calmon and Fawaz (2012). They regard the tradeoff as a convex optimization problem. This problem aims at minimizing the log-loss by the mutual information between the private data and released data,under the constraint that the average distortion between the original and the distorted data is bounded. Reed (1973); Yamamoto (1983); Sankar et al. (2013) provided asymptotic results on the rate-distortion-equivocation region with an increasing number of sampled data. du Pin Calmon and Fawaz (2012) modeled non-asymptotic privacy guarantees in terms of the inference cost gain achieved by an adversary through the released output.

Wang et al. (2016) measured distortion using the expected Hamming distance between the input and output databases,and measured privacy leakage using identifiability,differential privacy,and mutual-information privacy separately. The relation between these distinct privacy measurements was established under a unified privacy-distortion framework. Rassouli and Gündüz (2019) illustrated that the optimal utility-privacy trade-off can be solved using a standard linear program,using total variation distance to measure the privacy. The utility was measured using mutual information,minimum mean-square error (MMSE), and probability of error. Wang and Calmon (2017) provided a trade-off when utility and privacy were both evaluated using χ2superscript𝜒2\chi^{2}-based information measures. du Pin Calmon and Fawaz (2012) and Rassouli and Gündüz (2019) quantified the utility-privacy trade-off using the solution of the optimization problem. However,they could only provide a closed-form solution for the special case when Y𝑌Y is a binary variable. The utility was defined as the distortion. We measure the utility-privacy trade-off from a distinct point of view. By exploiting some key properties of the privacy leakage and the triangle inequality of the divergence,we provide a quantitative relationship which holds in general.

4. Privacy-Preserving FL Framework

In this section, we introduce the framework for the protection and the attacking mechanisms.

4.1. Threat Model

We consider the scenario where the server is a semi-honest attacker. The attacker is honest-but-curious. He/she adheres to the algorithm, and may infer the private information of the clients upon observing the uploaded information. We essentially follow the commonly used data reconstruction attacking model ((Zhu et al., 2019)). The attacker is aware of the following information:

  • •

    Machine learning model F𝐹F;

  • •

    Model parameter uploaded to the server;

  • •

    The average gradient calculated using a collection of M training samples;

  • •

    The size of the mini-batch;

  • •

    Label information (optional).

The semi-honest attacker is aware of the label information {Y1,⋯,Ym}subscript𝑌1⋯subscript𝑌𝑚\{Y_{1},\cdots,Y_{m}\}, upon observing the distorted model parameter W~~𝑊\widetilde{W}, he infers the feature information {X~1,⋯,X~m}subscript~𝑋1⋯subscript~𝑋𝑚\{\widetilde{X}_{1},\cdots,\widetilde{X}_{m}\}. Notice that the machine learning model F𝐹F and model parameter W𝑊W with respect to which the gradient is calculated are known to the adversary.

The protector obtains a mini-batch from his dataset. The mini-batch is denoted as 𝒟={X,Y}={(X1,Y1),⋯,(Xm,Ym)}𝒟XYsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑌1⋯subscript𝑋𝑚subscript𝑌𝑚\mathcal{D}=\{\textbf{X},\textbf{Y}\}=\{(X_{1},Y_{1}),\cdots,(X_{m},Y_{m})\}. The protector generates the true gradient ∇W∇𝑊\nabla W using 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}: ∂ℒ​(F​(X,W),Y)∂Wℒ𝐹X𝑊Y𝑊\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}(F(\textbf{X},W),\textbf{Y})}{\partial W}. The protector uploads the distorted gradient ∇W~~∇𝑊\widetilde{\nabla W}.

4.2. Protection Mechanism

FedAvg and FedSGD, two theoretically comparable representative aggregation implementations from HFL, are covered by our framework. We use FedAvg as an example to demonstrate how secure horizontal federated learning works. We consider the following scenario,

  1. (1)

    Each client k𝑘k samples a mini-batch 𝒟(k)superscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{(k)}, also referred to as his private dataset;

  2. (2)

    Generate model parameter Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)} from private data 𝒟(k)superscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{(k)};

  3. (3)

    The updated model parameter Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)} is distorted as W~t(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}, and then uploaded to the server;

  4. (4)

    The server aggregates the received model parameters from the clients and generates a global model parameter.

Now we elaborate on three main procedures in detail.

Step 1: Mini-Batch Generation

Let M𝑀M represent the total size of the dataset, and N𝑁N represent the total number of rounds for sampling. Each data d∈𝒟(k)𝑑superscript𝒟𝑘d\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)} is sampled with probability p𝑝p, and thereby obtaining the mini-batch, denoted as 𝒮(k)superscript𝒮𝑘\mathcal{S}^{(k)}. This is also regarded as the private data the defender aims to protect.

Step 2: Parameter Optimization

With the global model state from the server, each client k𝑘k updates local model parameter Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)} using stochastic gradient descent with its own data set 𝒟(k)superscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{(k)}.

The server sends the aggregated model parameter Wasubscript𝑊𝑎W_{a} to each client, each client updates model parameter locally using stochastic gradient descent, and the updated model parameter of client k𝑘k is denoted as Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)}. We follow the update rule of stochastic gradient descent used by federated SGD (FedSGD) ((McMahan et al., 2017)). The model parameters at round t+1𝑡1t+1 are updated as:

(7) Wt+1(k)←Wt−ηt|𝒮t(k)|​∑i∈𝒮t(k)∇ℒt(k)​(Wt,di(k)),←superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘subscript𝑊𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑘subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑘∇subscriptsuperscriptℒ𝑘𝑡subscript𝑊𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘\displaystyle W_{t+1}^{(k)}\leftarrow W_{t}-\frac{\eta_{t}}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}^{(k)}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}^{(k)}}\nabla\mathcal{L}^{(k)}_{t}(W_{t},d_{i}^{(k)}),

where Wtsubscript𝑊𝑡W_{t} represents the federated model parameter at round t𝑡t, and ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} represents the learning rate.

Viewing the above process, we know that the dataset 𝒮t(k)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑘\mathcal{S}_{t}^{(k)} is mapped to a model parameter via stochastic gradient descent (SGD). As a result, the model parameter is related with the gradient of the loss on the dataset 𝒮t(k)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑘\mathcal{S}_{t}^{(k)}. This mapping is deterministic once 𝒮t(k)superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑡𝑘\mathcal{S}_{t}^{(k)} and the initial model parameter Wtsubscript𝑊𝑡W_{t} are fixed.

Step 3: Parameter Distortion

We now introduce federated learning procedures that preserve privacy via distorting the model parameter. The protection mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is defined as ℳ:𝒲→𝒲:ℳ→𝒲𝒲\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{W}\rightarrow\mathcal{W}, where 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} represents the domain of the model parameter. The updated model parameter Wt+1(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘W_{t+1}^{(k)} is distorted as W~t+1(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡1𝑘\widetilde{W}_{t+1}^{(k)}, and is then uploaded to the server,

(8) W~t+1(k)=Wt+1(k)+δt+1(k).superscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑡1𝑘\displaystyle\widetilde{W}_{t+1}^{(k)}=W_{t+1}^{(k)}+\delta_{t+1}^{(k)}.

The server aggregates the received model parameters from the clients as an aggregated model parameter,

(9) W~t+1=1K​∑k=1KW~t+1(k).subscript~𝑊𝑡11𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡1𝑘\displaystyle\widetilde{W}_{t+1}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\widetilde{W}_{t+1}^{(k)}.

5. HFL Algorithms with near-optimal Utility

Our goal is to design a sampling strategy that satisfies the privacy constraint, and at the same time achieving near-optimal utility. Given the privacy budget τp,t(k)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘\tau_{p,t}^{(k)} for client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t, the total variation distance between two distributions is then calculated via Lemma 6.6. We use the randomization mechanism as an illustrative example, which adds a random noise following the normal distribution on the transmitted model parameter. The subroutine DistortModelParameter adds noise according to the calculated variance for randomization mechanism. The variance of the added noise is further derived according to Lemma 6.7, which guarantees the privacy constraint is satisfied. With the calculated total variation distance and the theoretical result illustrated in Theorem 6.1, the sampling probability for achieving near-optimal utility is then calculated via Eq. (19) (Theorem 6.11 in Section 6.2). With the calculated sampling probability, the client constructs a mini-batch 𝒮(k)superscript𝒮𝑘\mathcal{S}^{(k)} from his dataset 𝒟(k)superscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{(k)}. The client then updates his model parameter with the mini-batch 𝒮(k)superscript𝒮𝑘\mathcal{S}^{(k)}. These observations lead to our algorithm that achieves near-optimal utility and simultaneously satisfies the requirements that the privacy leakage of client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t does not exceed τp,t(k)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘\tau_{p,t}^{(k)}.

Theorem 6.1 states that ϵu,t(k)≤−𝔼(Var[W~t(k)|Wt−1(k)])+C6⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)}\leq-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}^{(k)}])+C_{6}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}). When the sampling probability p𝑝p satisfies that

(10) p⋅(1−p)⋅∑i=1M(∇ℒ​(Wt−1(k),di))2≤τp,t(k),⋅𝑝1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscript∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘subscript𝑑𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘\displaystyle p\cdot(1-p)\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{M}\left(\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i})\right)^{2}\leq\tau_{p,t}^{(k)},

the utility loss is 00, and meanwhile the privacy leakage is at most τp,t(k)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘\tau_{p,t}^{(k)}. We can near-optimal utility via adjusting the sampling probability p𝑝p for constructing the mini-batch according to Eq. (10). The subroutine ClientModelTraining updates the model parameters locally using the private data of client k𝑘k.

6. Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we introduce our main theorem (Theorem 6.1), which provides an avenue for achieving near-optimal utility. We provide upper bounds for utility loss and privacy leakage using sum of squares and bias-variance decomposition.

To derive the bounds for utility loss, we need the following assumptions.

Assumption 6.1.

Assume that ‖W‖∈[0,C3]norm𝑊0subscript𝐶3\|W\|\in[0,C_{3}] for any W∈𝒲(k)𝑊superscript𝒲𝑘W\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)}.

Assumption 6.2.

Assume that ‖𝔼​[W]−W∗‖∈[0,C4]norm𝔼delimited-[]𝑊superscript𝑊0subscript𝐶4\|\mathbb{E}[W]-W^{*}\|\in[0,C_{4}] for any W∈𝒲(k)𝑊superscript𝒲𝑘W\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)}.

6.1. Upper Bound for Utility Loss

Let Pt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑘P_{t}^{(k)} represent the distribution of Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)}, and P~t(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑃𝑡𝑘\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)} represent the distribution of W~t(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}, then TV​(Pt(k),P~t(k))TVsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝑃𝑡𝑘\text{TV}(P_{t}^{(k)},\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}) represents the distance between the distributions of Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)} and W~t(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}.

The following theorem shows that the utility loss is bounded by the distance between the protected and unprotected distributions. The distribution of the distorted model parameter P~t(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑃𝑡𝑘\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)} and that of the original model parameter Pt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑘P_{t}^{(k)} are distinct, and lead to a certain level of bias. Please refer to Section L for the full proof.

Theorem 6.1.

Let ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} be defined in Definition 3, then we have that

(11) ϵu,t(k)≤−𝔼(Var[W~t(k)|Wt−1(k)])+C6⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)),\displaystyle\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)}\leq-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}^{(k)}])+C_{6}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}),

where the first term is related to generalization in the stochastic gradient descent procedure, and the second term is related to the protection mechanism.

Remark: The upper bound for utility loss informs us that under some circumstances, the utility will not decrease but instead will increase. The performance of the model is governed by the distance between the original model parameter and its distorted counterpart and the sampling probability.

Remark: The analysis of this theorem consists of two main steps. First, we present the bias-variance decomposition. Then, we provide bounds for bias and variance separately. The law of variance is a generalized version of the sum-of-squares identity. The total variation is decomposed as the summation of variation within treatments and the variation between treatments.

In the following lemma we decompose the utility of client k𝑘k as the summation of variance and the bias. Please refer to Section D for the full proof.

Lemma 6.2 (Bias-Variance Decomposition for Sum of Squares).

Let Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)} represent the model parameter of client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t. Then we have that

GAP​(Wt(k))GAPsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\text{GAP}(W_{t}^{(k)}) =tr​(Var​[Wt(k)])⏟variance+Bias2​(Wt(k))⏟bias.absentsubscript⏟trVardelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘variancesubscript⏟superscriptBias2superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘bias\displaystyle=\underbrace{\text{tr}(\text{Var}[W_{t}^{(k)}])}_{\textbf{variance}}+\underbrace{\text{Bias}^{2}(W_{t}^{(k)})}_{\textbf{bias}}.

Remark: In this lemma we show that GAP​(Wt(k))GAPsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘\text{GAP}(W_{t}^{(k)}) with the sum-of-squares form could be decomposed as the summation of bias and variance. The bias of the original estimator Bias​(Wt(k))Biassuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)}) measures the gap of the utility using the true parameter and the estimated parameter (the bias of the original estimator is small is a basic requirement of the estimator).

The bias measures the gap of the utility using the true parameter and the estimated parameter. The bound for the bias gap is illustrated in the following lemma. Please refer to Appendix E for the full proof.

Lemma 6.3.

Let W∗superscript𝑊W^{*} denote the optimal model parameter, i.e., W∗=arg⁡minW⁡1N​∑i=1Nℒ​(W,di)superscript𝑊subscript𝑊1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁ℒ𝑊subscript𝑑𝑖W^{*}=\arg\min_{W}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathcal{L}(W,d_{i}), where N𝑁N represents the size of the mini-batch. Let Bias​(Wt(k))=‖𝔼​[Wt(k)]−W∗‖Biassuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘norm𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘superscript𝑊\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})=\|\mathbb{E}[W_{t}^{(k)}]-W^{*}\|. We have that

|Bias​(W~t(k))−Bias​(Wt(k))|Biassuperscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡𝑘Biassuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\bigg{|}\text{Bias}(\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)})-\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})\bigg{|} ≤C3⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)),\displaystyle\leq C_{3}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}),

where Wt(k)=Wt−1(k)−1|𝒟(k)|​∑i=1|𝒟(k)|∇ℒ​(Wt−1(k),di(k))superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘1superscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1superscript𝒟𝑘∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘W_{t}^{(k)}=W_{t-1}^{(k)}-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}^{(k)}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{D}^{(k)}|}\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i}^{(k)}), and W~t(k)=Wt(k)+δt(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑡𝑘\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}=W_{t}^{(k)}+\delta_{t}^{(k)}.

The variance represents the variation of the estimated values based on distinct datasets. The bound for the variance gap is illustrated in the following lemma. Please refer to Appendix F for the full proof.

Lemma 6.4 (Variance Gap).

Let N𝑁N represent the size of the mini-batch. We have that

(12) Var(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1(k)])−Var(Wt(k))≤−𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)|Wt−1(k)])⏟variance reduction+2sup∥W∥2C3⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)).\displaystyle\text{Var}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}^{(k)}])-\text{Var}(W_{t}^{(k)})\leq\underbrace{-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}^{(k)}])}_{\text{variance reduction}}+2\sup\|W\|_{2}C_{3}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}).

With the above lemmas, we are now ready to prove Theorem 6.1. Let −𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)])𝔼Vardelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}]) represent the variance reduction. This theorem provides an upper bound for utility loss, using the variance reduction and the total variation distance between the distorted distribution and the original distribution. From Theorem 6.1, we know that when 𝔼(Var[W~t(k)])=C3⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}])=C_{3}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}), the utility loss is of client k𝑘k is 00.

6.2. Sampling Probability for Achieving Near-optimal Utility in Privacy-preserving Federated Learning

Let ξ=maxk∈[K]⁡ξ(k)𝜉subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscript𝜉𝑘\xi=\max_{k\in[K]}\xi^{(k)}, ξ(k)=maxw∈𝒲(k),d∈𝒟(k)⁡|log⁡(fD(k)|W(k)​(d|w)fD(k)​(d))|superscript𝜉𝑘subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤superscript𝒲𝑘𝑑superscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscript𝐷𝑘superscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓superscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\xi^{(k)}=\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)},d\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D^{(k)}|W^{(k)}}(d|w)}{f_{D^{(k)}}(d)}\right)\right| represent the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, and [K]={1,2,⋯,K}delimited-[]𝐾12⋯𝐾[K]=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}. We define

(13) C2=12​(e2​ξ−1),subscript𝐶212superscript𝑒2𝜉1\displaystyle C_{2}=\frac{1}{2}(e^{2\xi}-1),

and

(14) C1,t=1K​∑k=1KJS(Ft(k)||F~t(k)).\displaystyle C_{1,t}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{F}^{(k)}_{t})}.

The following lemma illustrates that the privacy leakage could be upper bounded using the total variation distance between Pt(k)subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘𝑡P^{(k)}_{t} and P~t(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑃𝑡𝑘\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}.

Lemma 6.5 (Upper Bound for Privacy Leakage).

Let Ft(k)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑡F^{(k)}_{t} and F~t(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑘𝑡\widetilde{F}^{(k)}_{t} represent the belief of client k𝑘k about S𝑆S before and after observing the original parameter. Let Pt(k)subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘𝑡P^{(k)}_{t} and P~t(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑃𝑡𝑘\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)} represent the distribution of the parameter of client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t before and after being protected. Assume that C2⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))≤C1,tC_{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)})\leq C_{1,t}. The upper bound for the privacy leakage of client k𝑘k is

ϵp,t(k)≤2C1,t−C2⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)),\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}\leq 2C_{1,t}-C_{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}),

where C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} is introduced in Eq. (13), and C1,tsubscript𝐶1𝑡C_{1,t} is introduced in Eq. (14).

Remark: Intuitively, the privacy leakage decreases as the total variation distance increases, which is consistent with this upper bound.

Given the requirement on privacy leakage, we can determine the least amount of distortion extent. Please refer to Section H for the full proof.

Lemma 6.6.

Let C1,t=1K​∑k=1KJS(Ft(k)||F~t(k))C_{1,t}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{F}^{(k)}_{t})}. If the total variation distance is at least

(15) TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))≥C1,t−τp,t(k),\displaystyle\operatorname{TV}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)})\geq C_{1,t}-\tau_{p,t}^{(k)},

then the privacy leakage ϵp,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)} is at most τp,t(k)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘\tau_{p,t}^{(k)}, where C1,tsubscript𝐶1𝑡C_{1,t} is introduced in Eq. (14).

Remark: The total variation distance between the distributions of the distorted model parameter P~t(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑃𝑡𝑘\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)} and that of the original model parameter Pt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑘P_{t}^{(k)} serves as an upper bound for privacy leakage. With the requirement on the maximum amount of privacy leakage, we are now ready to derive a lower bound for the total variation distance.

The relationship between the total variation distance and the variance of the added noise is illustrated in the following lemma.

Lemma 6.7 ((Zhang et al., 2022a, b)).

Let σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} represent the variance of the original model parameter, and σϵ2superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2} represent the variance of the added noise. Then

(16) 1100min{1,σϵ2​dσ2}≤TV(P(k)||P~(k))≤32min{1,σϵ2​dσ2},\frac{1}{100}\min\left\{1,\frac{\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\sqrt{d}}{\sigma^{2}}\right\}\leq{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)})\leq\frac{3}{2}\min\left\{1,\frac{\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\sqrt{d}}{\sigma^{2}}\right\},

where d𝑑d represents the number of dimension of the parameter.

Please refer to Section I for the full analysis.

Lemma 6.8.

Assume that 0<C1,t−τp,t(k)<0.010subscript𝐶1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘0.010<C_{1,t}-\tau_{p,t}^{(k)}<0.01, where C1,tsubscript𝐶1𝑡C_{1,t} is introduced in Eq. (14). Let σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} represent the variance of the original model parameter, and σϵ2superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2} represent the variance of the added noise. If the variance of the added noise σϵ2=100​σ2​(C1,t−τp,t(k))dsuperscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2100superscript𝜎2subscript𝐶1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘𝑑\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}=\frac{100\sigma^{2}(C_{1,t}-\tau_{p,t}^{(k)})}{\sqrt{d}}, then the privacy leakage ϵp,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)} is at most τp,t(k)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘\tau_{p,t}^{(k)}.

Remark: Given the variance of the added noise, we can guarantee that the lower bound of the total variation distance between the distributions of the distorted model parameter P~t(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑃𝑡𝑘\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)} and that of the original model parameter Pt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑘P_{t}^{(k)} from Lemma 6.7. Combined with Lemma 6.6, it is guaranteed that the privacy leakage ϵp,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)} is at most τp,t(k)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘\tau_{p,t}^{(k)}.

The following lemma calculates the expectation of the model parameter W~t(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}. Please refer to Section J for the full proof.

Lemma 6.9.

Let W~t(k)=Wt−1(k)−1N∑j=1N∑i=1M∇ℒ(Wt−1(k),di(k))𝟙{di(k) is selected at \widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}=W_{t-1}^{(k)}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\sum_{i=1}^{M}\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i}^{(k)})\mathbbm{1}\{d_{i}^{(k)}\text{ is selected at }j-th round}+δt−1(k)\text{th}\text{ round}\}+\delta_{t-1}^{(k)}, where M𝑀M represents the data size, and N𝑁N represents the total number of rounds for sampling. We have that

(17) 𝔼​[W~t(k)]=Wt−1(k)−p⋅∑i=1M∇ℒ​(Wt−1(k),di(k))+δt−1(k).𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘⋅𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑡1𝑘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}]=W_{t-1}^{(k)}-p\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{M}\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i}^{(k)})+\delta_{t-1}^{(k)}.

Remark: The expectation of the distorted model parameter is related to the sampling probability p𝑝p and the added noise δt−1(k)superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑡1𝑘\delta_{t-1}^{(k)}.

With the expectation of the distorted model parameter, the following theorem further calculates the variance of the distorted model parameter W~t(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}. Fixing Wt−1(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘W_{t-1}^{(k)} and data disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i}, then Var​[W~t(k)]Vardelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}] depends on p𝑝p. Please refer to Appendix K for the full proof.

Theorem 6.10.

We denote p𝑝p as the sampling probability. That is, each data of each client is sampled with probability p𝑝p to generate the batch. Let W~t(k)=Wt−1(k)−1N​∑i=1N∇ℒ​(Wt−1(k),di(k))+δt−1(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑡1𝑘\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}=W_{t-1}^{(k)}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i}^{(k)})+\delta_{t-1}^{(k)}, where M𝑀M represents the data size, and N𝑁N represents the total number of rounds for sampling. We have that

(18) Var​[W~t(k)]=p⋅(1−p)⋅∑i=1M(∇ℒ​(Wt−1(k),di(k)))2.Vardelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡⋅𝑝1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscript∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘2\displaystyle\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}]=p\cdot(1-p)\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{M}\left(\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i}^{(k)})\right)^{2}.

Remark: The variance of the distorted model parameter is related to the sampling probability and the gradient of the dataset.

With the following theorem, we can find the optimal sampling probability for achieving near-optimal utility, and meanwhile satisfies the requirement on privacy.

Theorem 6.11.

Let Assumption 6.2 hold. Given the requirement that the privacy leakage ϵp,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)} should not exceed τp,t(k)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘\tau_{p,t}^{(k)}. If the sampling probability p𝑝p satisfies

(19) p​(1−p)≥C6⋅(C1,t−τp,t(k))∑i=1M(∇ℒ​(Wt−1(k),di))2,𝑝1𝑝⋅subscript𝐶6subscript𝐶1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑝𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscript∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘subscript𝑑𝑖2\displaystyle p(1-p)\geq\frac{C_{6}\cdot(C_{1,t}-\tau_{p,t}^{(k)})}{\sum_{i=1}^{M}\left(\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i})\right)^{2}},

then client k𝑘k achieves near-optimal utility, where C1,tsubscript𝐶1𝑡C_{1,t} is introduced in Eq. (14), and C4subscript𝐶4C_{4} is introduced in Assumption 6.2.

Remark: Let −𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)])𝔼Vardelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}]) represent the variance reduction. Theorem 6.1 provides an upper bound for utility loss, using the variance reduction and the total variation distance between the distorted distribution and the original distribution. From Theorem 6.1, we know that when 𝔼(Var[W~t(k)])=C6⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}])=C_{6}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}), the utility loss is of client k𝑘k is 00. Theorem 6.10 illustrates that the variance of the distorted model parameter is related to the sampling probability and the gradient of the dataset. Lemma 6.6 provides a lower bound for total variation distance. Therefore, when the sampling probability p𝑝p satisfies Eq. (19), then client k𝑘k achieves near-optimal utility.

6.3. Optimal Trade-off Between Utility Loss and Privacy Leakage

In this section, we derive the optimal trade-off between utility loss and privacy leakage. Please refer to Section O for the full proof.

The following theorem provides an upper bound for utility loss of client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t.

Theorem 6.12 (Upper Bound for Trade-off).

Let Assumption 6.1 and Assumption 6.2 hold. We have that

ϵp,t(k)+C2C6⋅ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}+\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}\cdot\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} ≤−C2C6⋅𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)|Wt−1(k)])+2​C1,t(k).absent⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6𝔼Vardelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\leq-\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}\cdot\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}^{(k)}])+2C_{1,t}^{(k)}.

where C1,t(k)=JS(Ft(k)||F~t(k))C_{1,t}^{(k)}=\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{F}^{(k)}_{t})}, C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} is introduced in Eq. (13), and C6subscript𝐶6C_{6} is introduced in Theorem 6.1.

Remark: Theorem 6.1 illustrates the upper bound of utility loss using variance reduction and the total variation distance. Lemma 6.5 presents the relationship between the total variation distance and the privacy leakage. Combining Theorem 6.1 and Lemma 6.5, we can express the upper bound of utility loss using privacy leakage.

The following theorem provides a lower bound for trade-off between privacy and utility.

Theorem 6.13 (Lower Bound for Trade-off, see Theorem 4.1 of (Zhang et al., 2022a)).

Let ϵp,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)} be defined in Definition 4, and let ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} be defined in Definition 3, with Assumption C.1 we have:

(20) ϵp,t(k)+Cd⋅ϵu,t(k)≥C1,t(k),superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘⋅subscript𝐶𝑑superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}+C_{d}\cdot\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)}\geq C_{1,t}^{(k)},

where C1,t(k)=JS(Ft(k)||F~t(k))C_{1,t}^{(k)}=\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{F}^{(k)}_{t})}, Cd=γ4​Δ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑑𝛾4Δsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{d}=\frac{\gamma}{4\Delta}(e^{2\xi}-1), where ξ(k)superscript𝜉𝑘\xi^{(k)}=maxw∈𝒲(k),d∈𝒟(k)⁡|log⁡(fD(k)|W(k)​(d|w)fD(k)​(d))|subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤superscript𝒲𝑘𝑑superscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscript𝐷𝑘superscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓superscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)},d\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D^{(k)}|W^{(k)}}(d|w)}{f_{D^{(k)}}(d)}\right)\right|, ξ𝜉\xi=maxk∈[K]⁡ξ(k)subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscript𝜉𝑘\max_{k\in[K]}\xi^{(k)} represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, and ΔΔ\Delta is introduced in Assumption C.1.

Remark: This theorem states that the summation of privacy leakage and utility loss against the semi-honest attacker is constrained by a constant. The utility of the model may be diminished if privacy protection is strengthened, and vice versa. Notice that γ=∑k=1KTV(P(k)||P~(k))TV(Pa||P~a)\gamma=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)})}{{\text{TV}}(P_{a}||\widetilde{P}_{a})}. From Lemma C.2 of (Zhang et al., 2022a), 1150≤γ≤1501150𝛾150\frac{1}{150}\leq\gamma\leq 150.

With the upper bound and lower bound for trade off between privacy and utility, we are ready to derive the condition for achieving optimal trade-off, which is illustrated in the following theorem.

Theorem 6.14 (Optimal Trade-off).

Consider the scenario where Cd=C2C6subscript𝐶𝑑subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6C_{d}=\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}. If C1,t(k)=C2C6⋅𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)|Wt−1(k)])superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6𝔼Vardelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘C_{1,t}^{(k)}=\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}\cdot\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}^{(k)}]), then the optimal trade-off is achieved, where C1,t(k)=JS(Ft(k)||F~t(k))C_{1,t}^{(k)}=\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{F}^{(k)}_{t})}, Cd=γ4​Δ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑑𝛾4Δsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{d}=\frac{\gamma}{4\Delta}(e^{2\xi}-1), where ξ(k)superscript𝜉𝑘\xi^{(k)}=maxw∈𝒲(k),d∈𝒟(k)⁡|log⁡(fD(k)|W(k)​(d|w)fD(k)​(d))|subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤superscript𝒲𝑘𝑑superscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscript𝐷𝑘superscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓superscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)},d\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D^{(k)}|W^{(k)}}(d|w)}{f_{D^{(k)}}(d)}\right)\right|, ξ𝜉\xi=maxk∈[K]⁡ξ(k)subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscript𝜉𝑘\max_{k\in[K]}\xi^{(k)} represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, ΔΔ\Delta is introduced in Assumption C.1, and C6subscript𝐶6C_{6} is introduced in Theorem 6.1.

7. Conclusion and Future Works

We measure the utility via the gap between the original model parameter and the distorted model parameter, and provide an upper bound for utility loss via bias-variance decomposition. Based on this upper bound, we provide an algorithm that achieves near-optimal utility, and meanwhile satisfies the requirement on privacy leakage. The main techniques of the proposed protection mechanism are parameter distortion and data generation, which are generic and have a wide range of applications. Furthermore, we derive an upper bound for the trade-off between privacy and utility, which when combined with the lower bound shown in NFL, creates the prerequisites for obtaining the best possible trade-off.

(Zhang et al., 2022a) illustrated that the privacy leakage could be lower bounded by the total variation distance between Pt(k)subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘𝑡P^{(k)}_{t} and P~t(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝑃𝑘𝑡\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}, as is shown in the following lemma.

For two positive numbers a𝑎a and b𝑏b, we have that

|log⁡(ab)|≤|a−b|min⁡{a,b}.𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏\displaystyle\left|\log\left(\frac{a}{b}\right)\right|\leq\frac{|a-b|}{\min\{a,b\}}.

Appendix C Assumption of previous work

Definition C.0 (Optimal parameters).

Let 𝒲a∗subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝑎\mathcal{W}^{*}_{a} represent the set of parameters achieving the maximum utility. Specifically,

𝒲a∗=argmaxw∈𝒲a1K​∑k=1KU(k)​(w),subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝑎subscriptargmax𝑤subscript𝒲𝑎1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝑈𝑘𝑤\displaystyle\mathcal{W}^{*}_{a}=\operatorname*{argmax}_{w\in\mathcal{W}_{a}}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}U^{(k)}(w),

Definition C.0 (Near-optimal parameters).

Let 𝒲~asubscript~𝒲𝑎\widetilde{\mathcal{W}}_{a} represent the support of the protected distribution of the aggregated model information. Given a non-negative constant c𝑐c, the near-optimal parameters is defined as

𝒲c={w∈𝒲~a:|1K​∑k=1KU(k)​(w∗)−1K​∑k=1KU(k)​(w)|≤c,∀w∗∈𝒲a∗}.subscript𝒲𝑐conditional-set𝑤subscript~𝒲𝑎formulae-sequence1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝑈𝑘superscript𝑤1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝑈𝑘𝑤𝑐for-allsuperscript𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝒲𝑎\mathcal{W}_{c}=\left\{w\in\widetilde{\mathcal{W}}_{a}:\left|\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}U^{(k)}(w^{*})-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}U^{(k)}(w)\right|\leq c,\forall w^{*}\in\mathcal{W}^{*}_{a}\right\}.
Assumption C.1.

Let ΔΔ\Delta be the maximum constant that satisfies

(26) ∫𝒲~ap~Wa​(w)​𝟙​{w∈𝒲Δ}​𝑑w≤TV(Pa||P~a)2,\displaystyle\int_{\widetilde{\mathcal{W}}_{a}}\widetilde{p}_{W_{a}}(w)\mathbbm{1}\{w\in\mathcal{W}_{\Delta}\}dw\leq\frac{{\text{TV}}(P_{a}||\widetilde{P}_{a})}{2},

where p~~𝑝\widetilde{p} represents the probability density function of the protected model information. We assume that ΔΔ\Delta is positive, i.e., Δ>0Δ0\Delta>0.

Remark:
(1) This assumption implies that the cumulative density of the near-optimal parameters as defined in Def. 2 is bounded. This assumption excludes the cases where the utility function is constant or indistinguishable between the optimal parameters and a certain fraction of parameters.
(2) Note that Δ(k)superscriptΔ𝑘\Delta^{(k)} is independent of the threat model of the adversary and Δ(k)superscriptΔ𝑘\Delta^{(k)} is a constant when the protection mechanism, the utility function, and the data sets are fixed.

First, we present the bias-variance decomposition. Then, we provide bounds for bias and variance separately.

Appendix E Analysis for Lemma 6.3

Let P(k)superscript𝑃𝑘P^{(k)} represent the distribution of Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)}, and P~(k)superscript~𝑃𝑘\widetilde{P}^{(k)} represent the distribution of W~t(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡𝑘\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}. Now we provide an upper bound for the gap using total variation distance. The total variation distance measures the distance between the distributions of the distorted parameter and the true parameter. Recall that Wt(k)=Wt−1(k)−1|𝒟(k)|​∑i=1𝒟(k)∇ℒ​(Wt−1(k),di)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘1superscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1superscript𝒟𝑘∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘subscript𝑑𝑖W_{t}^{(k)}=W_{t-1}^{(k)}-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}^{(k)}|}\sum_{i=1}^{\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i}).

Lemma E.1.

We define C​(W)=‖W‖𝐶𝑊norm𝑊C(W)=\|W\|. Let Assumption 6.1 hold. That is, C​(W)∈[0,C3]𝐶𝑊0subscript𝐶3C(W)\in[0,C_{3}] for any W∈𝒲(k)𝑊superscript𝒲𝑘W\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)}. We have that

|𝔼[C(W~t(k))]−𝔼[C(Wt(k))]|≤C3⋅TV(P~t(k)||Pt(k)),\displaystyle\left|\mathbb{E}[C(\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t})]-\mathbb{E}[C(W_{t}^{(k)})]\right|\leq C_{3}\cdot\operatorname{TV}(\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}||P^{(k)}_{t}),

where the expectation is taken over the randomness of Wt(k)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘W_{t}^{(k)} and the randomness of distortion.

Proof.

Lemma E.2.

We define C​(W)=‖𝔼​[W]−W∗‖𝐶𝑊norm𝔼delimited-[]𝑊superscript𝑊C(W)=\|\mathbb{E}[W]-W^{*}\|. Let Assumption 6.2 hold. That is, C​(W)∈[0,C4]𝐶𝑊0subscript𝐶4C(W)\in[0,C_{4}] for any W∈𝒲(k)𝑊superscript𝒲𝑘W\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)}. We have that

|𝔼[C(W~t(k))]−𝔼[C(Wt(k))]|≤C4⋅TV(P~t(k)||Pt(k)),\displaystyle\left|\mathbb{E}[C(\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t})]-\mathbb{E}[C(W_{t}^{(k)})]\right|\leq C_{4}\cdot\operatorname{TV}(\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}||P^{(k)}_{t}),

With Lemma E.2, we are now ready to derive bounds for bias gap and variance gap. The bias gap is illustrated in the following lemma.

Lemma E.3.

Let W∗superscript𝑊W^{*} denote the optimal model parameter, i.e., W∗=arg⁡minW⁡1N​∑i=1Nℒ​(W,di)superscript𝑊subscript𝑊1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁ℒ𝑊subscript𝑑𝑖W^{*}=\arg\min_{W}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathcal{L}(W,d_{i}). |Bias(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])−Bias(Wt(k))|\displaystyle\big{|}\text{Bias}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])-\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})\big{|} ≤C4⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)),\displaystyle\leq C_{4}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}),

where Wt(k)=Wt−1(k)−1|𝒟(k)|​∑i=1𝒟(k)∇ℒ​(Wt−1(k),di(k))superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘1superscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1superscript𝒟𝑘∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑘W_{t}^{(k)}=W_{t-1}^{(k)}-\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}^{(k)}|}\sum_{i=1}^{\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\nabla\mathcal{L}(W_{t-1}^{(k)},d_{i}^{(k)}), and W~t(k)=Wt(k)+δt(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑡𝑘\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}=W_{t}^{(k)}+\delta_{t}^{(k)}.

Proof.

Recall that Bias​(Wt(k))=𝔼​[‖𝔼​[Wt(k)]−W∗‖]Biassuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘𝔼delimited-[]norm𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘superscript𝑊\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})=\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbb{E}[W_{t}^{(k)}]-W^{*}\|]. Therefore, we have that

(27) ≤C4⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)),\displaystyle\leq C_{4}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}),

where the inequality is due to Lemma E.2. ∎

Appendix F Analysis for Variance Gap (Lemma 6.4)

Appendix G Analysis for Lemma 6.5

The following lemma illustrates that the privacy leakage could be upper bounded by the total variation distance between Pt(k)subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘𝑡P^{(k)}_{t} and P~(k)superscript~𝑃𝑘\widetilde{P}^{(k)}.

Lemma G.1 (Upper Bound for Privacy Leakage).

Let Ft(k)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑘𝑡F^{(k)}_{t} and F~t(k)subscriptsuperscript~𝐹𝑘𝑡\widetilde{F}^{(k)}_{t} represent the belief of client k𝑘k about S𝑆S after observing the original parameter and the protected parameter. Let C1,t(k)=JS(F˘t(k)||Ft(k))C_{1,t}^{(k)}=\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t}||F^{(k)}_{t})}, and C2=12​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶212superscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{2}=\frac{1}{2}(e^{2\xi}-1), where ξ=maxk∈[K]⁡ξ(k)𝜉subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscript𝜉𝑘\xi=\max_{k\in[K]}\xi^{(k)}, ξ(k)=maxw∈𝒲(k),d∈𝒟(k)⁡|log⁡(fD(k)|W(k)​(d|w)fD(k)​(d))|superscript𝜉𝑘subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤superscript𝒲𝑘𝑑superscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscript𝐷𝑘superscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓superscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\xi^{(k)}=\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)},d\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D^{(k)}|W^{(k)}}(d|w)}{f_{D^{(k)}}(d)}\right)\right| represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, and [K]={1,2,⋯,K}delimited-[]𝐾12⋯𝐾[K]=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}. Let Pt(k)subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘𝑡P^{(k)}_{t} and P~t(k)superscriptsubscript~𝑃𝑡𝑘\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)} represent the distribution of the parameter of client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t before and after being protected. Assume that C2⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))≤C1,t(k)C_{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)})\leq C_{1,t}^{(k)}. The upper bound for the privacy leakage of client k𝑘k is

ϵp,t(k)≤2C1,t(k)−C2⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)).\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}\leq 2C_{1,t}^{(k)}-C_{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}).
Proof.

Notice that the square root of the Jensen-Shannon divergence satisfies the triangle inequality. ξ=maxk∈[K]⁡ξ(k)𝜉subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscript𝜉𝑘\xi=\max_{k\in[K]}\xi^{(k)}, ξ(k)=maxw∈𝒲(k),d∈𝒟(k)⁡|log⁡(fD(k)|W(k)​(d|w)fD(k)​(d))|superscript𝜉𝑘subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤superscript𝒲𝑘𝑑superscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscript𝐷𝑘superscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓superscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\xi^{(k)}=\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)},d\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D^{(k)}|W^{(k)}}(d|w)}{f_{D^{(k)}}(d)}\right)\right| represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, and [K]={1,2,⋯,K}delimited-[]𝐾12⋯𝐾[K]=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}. Fixing the attacking extent, then ξ𝜉\xi is a constant.

Then we have that

ϵp,t(k)=JS(F~t(k)||F˘t(k))\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}=\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(\widetilde{F}_{t}^{(k)}||\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t})} ≤JS(Ft(k)||F˘t(k))+JS(F~t(k)||Ft(k))\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t})}+\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(\widetilde{F}_{t}^{(k)}||F^{(k)}_{t})}
≤JS(Ft(k)||F˘t(k))+12⋅(e2​ξ−1)TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t})}+\frac{1}{2}\cdot(e^{2\xi}-1){\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t})
≤2JS(Ft(k)||F˘t(k))−12⋅(e2​ξ−1)TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))\displaystyle\leq 2\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t})}-\frac{1}{2}\cdot(e^{2\xi}-1){\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t})
=2C1,t(k)−C2⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)),\displaystyle=2C_{1,t}^{(k)}-C_{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}),

where the second inequality is due to Lemma B.3, and the third inequality is due to the assumption that C2⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))≤JS(Ft(k)||F˘t(k))C_{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t})\leq\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t})}. ∎

Appendix H Analysis for Lemma 6.6

Lemma H.1.

Let C1,t=1K​∑k=1KJS(Ft(k)||F˘t(k))C_{1,t}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t})}. If the total variation distance is at least

(31) TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))≥C1,t−τp,t(k),\displaystyle\operatorname{TV}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)})\geq C_{1,t}-\tau_{p,t}^{(k)},

(32) ϵp,t(k)≤C1,t−TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)).\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}\leq C_{1,t}-\operatorname{TV}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}).

where the first inequality is due to the upper bound of privacy leakage derived in Lemma 6.5. ∎

Appendix L Analysis for Theorem 6.1

In this section, we introduce our main theorem, which illustrates the condition for achieving near-optimal utility.

The following theorem shows that the utility loss is bounded by the distance between the protected and unprotected distributions. We provide an upper bound for utility loss using the property of sum of squares and bias-variance decomposition. This theorem informs how to obtain near-optimal utility. When 𝔼(Var[W~t(k)|Wt−1])=C6⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])=C_{6}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}), the utility loss is 00.

Theorem L.1 (Upper Bounds for Utility Loss).

Let ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} be defined in Definition 3, then we have that

(49) ϵu,t(k)≤−𝔼(Var[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+C6⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)),\displaystyle\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)}\leq-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])+C_{6}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}),

where the first term is related to generalization and corresponds to the stochastic gradient descent procedure, and the second term is related to the protection mechanism.

Proof.

From Lemma D.1, we have that

GAP​(Wt(k))=tr​(Var​[Wt(k)])⏟variance+Bias2​(Wt(k))⏟bias.GAPsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘subscript⏟trVardelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘variancesubscript⏟superscriptBias2superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘bias\displaystyle\text{GAP}(W_{t}^{(k)})=\underbrace{\text{tr}(\text{Var}[W_{t}^{(k)}])}_{\textbf{variance}}+\underbrace{\text{Bias}^{2}(W_{t}^{(k)})}_{\textbf{bias}}.

Therefore, we have that

ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} =GAP​(W~t(k))−GAP​(Wt(k))absentGAPsuperscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡𝑘GAPsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘\displaystyle=\text{GAP}(\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)})-\text{GAP}(W_{t}^{(k)})
=(Var​(𝔼​[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+Bias2​(𝔼​[W~t(k)|Wt−1]))−(Var​[Wt(k)]+Bias2​(Wt(k)))absentVar𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡𝑘subscript𝑊𝑡1superscriptBias2𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑡𝑘subscript𝑊𝑡1Vardelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘superscriptBias2superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑘\displaystyle=(\text{Var}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])+\text{Bias}^{2}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}]))-(\text{Var}[W_{t}^{(k)}]+\text{Bias}^{2}(W_{t}^{(k)}))
≤(Var(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])−Var[Wt(k)])+|Bias2(Wt(k))−Bias2(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])|.\displaystyle\leq(\text{Var}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])-\text{Var}[W_{t}^{(k)}])+|\text{Bias}^{2}(W_{t}^{(k)})-\text{Bias}^{2}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])|.

First we provide bounds for the gap of the bias.

Bounding Bias Gap

|Bias2(Wt(k))−Bias2(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])|\displaystyle\left|\text{Bias}^{2}(W_{t}^{(k)})-\text{Bias}^{2}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])\right|
=(Bias(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+Bias(Wt(k)))⋅|Bias(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])−Bias(Wt(k))|\displaystyle=\left(\text{Bias}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])+\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})\right)\cdot\big{|}\text{Bias}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])-\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})\big{|}
≤(|Bias(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])−Bias(Wt(k))|+2Bias(Wt(k)))⋅|Bias(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])−Bias(Wt(k))|.\displaystyle\leq\left(\big{|}\text{Bias}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])-\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})\big{|}+2\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})\right)\cdot\big{|}\text{Bias}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])-\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})\big{|}.

From Lemma E.3, we have that

|Bias(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])−Bias(Wt(k))|\displaystyle\big{|}\text{Bias}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])-\text{Bias}(W_{t}^{(k)})\big{|} ≤C4⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)).\displaystyle\leq C_{4}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}).

Therefore, we have

|Bias2(Wt(k))−Bias2(𝔼[W~t(k)|Wt−1])|\displaystyle\left|\text{Bias}^{2}(W_{t}^{(k)})-\text{Bias}^{2}(\mathbb{E}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])\right|

Bounding Variance

Therefore, we have

(51) ϵu,t(k)≤−𝔼(Var[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+C6⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)),\displaystyle\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)}\leq-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}_{t}^{(k)}|W_{t-1}])+C_{6}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}^{(k)}_{t}),

Let Assumption 6.1 and Assumption 6.2 hold. We have that

ϵp,t(k)+C2C4⋅ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶4superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}+\frac{C_{2}}{C_{4}}\cdot\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} ≤−C2C6⋅𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+2​C1,t(k).absent⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6𝔼Vardelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡subscript𝑊𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\leq-\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}\cdot\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}])+2C_{1,t}^{(k)}.

Proof.

(65) ϵu,t(k)≤−𝔼(Var[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+C6⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)).\displaystyle\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)}\leq-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}])+C_{6}\cdot\operatorname{TV}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}).

From Lemma 6.5, the relationship between the total variation distance and the privacy leakage is

(66) ϵp,t(k)≤2C1,t(k)−C2⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k)).\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}\leq 2C_{1,t}^{(k)}-C_{2}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P^{(k)}_{t}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)}).

Therefore, we have

ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} ≤−𝔼(Var[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+C6⋅TV(Pt(k)||P~t(k))\displaystyle\leq-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}])+C_{6}\cdot{\text{TV}}(P_{t}^{(k)}||\widetilde{P}_{t}^{(k)})
≤−𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+C6C2⋅(2​C1,t(k)−ϵp,t(k)).absent𝔼Vardelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡subscript𝑊𝑡1⋅subscript𝐶6subscript𝐶22superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\leq-\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}])+\frac{C_{6}}{C_{2}}\cdot(2C_{1,t}^{(k)}-\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}).

∎

O.2. Analysis for Theorem 6.14

Let ϵp,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)} be defined in Definition 4, let ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} be defined in Definition 3, and let Assumption C.1 hold. From No free lunch theorem (NFL) for privacy and utility, we have that ϵp,t(k)+Cd⋅ϵu,t(k)≥C1,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘⋅subscript𝐶𝑑superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}+C_{d}\cdot\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)}\geq C_{1,t}^{(k)}.

Theorem O.2 (Lower Bound for Trade-off, see Theorem 4.1 of (Zhang et al., 2022a)).

Let ϵp,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)} be defined in Definition 4, and let ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} be defined in Definition 3, with Assumption C.1 we have:

where C1,t(k)=JS(Ft(k)||F˘t(k))C_{1,t}^{(k)}=\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t})}, Cd=γ4​Δ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑑𝛾4Δsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{d}=\frac{\gamma}{4\Delta}(e^{2\xi}-1), where ξ(k)superscript𝜉𝑘\xi^{(k)}=maxw∈𝒲(k),d∈𝒟(k)⁡|log⁡(fD(k)|W(k)​(d|w)fD(k)​(d))|subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤superscript𝒲𝑘𝑑superscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscript𝐷𝑘superscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓superscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)},d\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D^{(k)}|W^{(k)}}(d|w)}{f_{D^{(k)}}(d)}\right)\right|, ξ𝜉\xi=maxk∈[K]⁡ξ(k)subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscript𝜉𝑘\max_{k\in[K]}\xi^{(k)} represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, and ΔΔ\Delta is introduced in Assumption C.1.

In certain scenarios, we provide the condition for achieving optimal trade-off.

Theorem O.3 (Optimal Trade-off).

Consider the scenario where Cd=C2C6subscript𝐶𝑑subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6C_{d}=\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}. If C1,t=C2C6⋅𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)|Wt−1])subscript𝐶1𝑡⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6𝔼Vardelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡subscript𝑊𝑡1C_{1,t}=\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}\cdot\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}]), then the optimal trade-off is achieved, where C1,t(k)=JS(Ft(k)||F˘t(k))C_{1,t}^{(k)}=\sqrt{{\text{JS}}(F^{(k)}_{t}||\breve{F}^{(k)}_{t})}, Cd=γ4​Δ​(e2​ξ−1)subscript𝐶𝑑𝛾4Δsuperscript𝑒2𝜉1C_{d}=\frac{\gamma}{4\Delta}(e^{2\xi}-1), where ξ(k)superscript𝜉𝑘\xi^{(k)}=maxw∈𝒲(k),d∈𝒟(k)⁡|log⁡(fD(k)|W(k)​(d|w)fD(k)​(d))|subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤superscript𝒲𝑘𝑑superscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑓conditionalsuperscript𝐷𝑘superscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤subscript𝑓superscript𝐷𝑘𝑑\max_{w\in\mathcal{W}^{(k)},d\in\mathcal{D}^{(k)}}\left|\log\left(\frac{f_{D^{(k)}|W^{(k)}}(d|w)}{f_{D^{(k)}}(d)}\right)\right|, ξ𝜉\xi=maxk∈[K]⁡ξ(k)subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscript𝜉𝑘\max_{k\in[K]}\xi^{(k)} represents the maximum privacy leakage over all possible information w𝑤w released by client k𝑘k, and ΔΔ\Delta is introduced in Assumption C.1, and C6subscript𝐶6C_{6} is introduced in Theorem 6.1.

Proof.

From Theorem O.1, we have

ϵp,t(k)+C2C6⋅ϵu,t(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}+\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}\cdot\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)} ≤−C2C6⋅𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)|Wt−1])+2​C1,t(k).absent⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6𝔼Vardelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡subscript𝑊𝑡12superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\leq-\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}\cdot\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}])+2C_{1,t}^{(k)}.

From Theorem O.2, we have

(68) ϵp,t(k)+Cd⋅ϵu,t(k)≥C1,t(k).superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑡𝑘⋅subscript𝐶𝑑superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon_{p,t}^{(k)}+C_{d}\cdot\epsilon_{u,t}^{(k)}\geq C_{1,t}^{(k)}.

By setting C1,t(k)=C2C6⋅𝔼​(Var​[W~t(k)|Wt−1])superscriptsubscript𝐶1𝑡𝑘⋅subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶6𝔼Vardelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscript~𝑊𝑘𝑡subscript𝑊𝑡1C_{1,t}^{(k)}=\frac{C_{2}}{C_{6}}\cdot\mathbb{E}(\text{Var}[\widetilde{W}^{(k)}_{t}|W_{t-1}]), the optimal trade-off is achieved. ∎
